I have a lot of thoughts on this class. I think the biggest weakness, which is no fault of the instructor, is the structure of the class. That's on the stubbornness of the department, which refuses to use any text other than a book by Shankar, which was written in the 90s, is riddled with errors, and is anything but lucid. I feel like this class could be fantastic and achieve the twin goals of both reviewing old math and introducing new concepts, but as it is, the class does both poorly, and I fully believe this is the fault of the book and syllabus, rather than any professor, since this has been a systemic problem with this course. At the beginning of the semester, a full two weeks is devoted to review of single variable calc, and multiple weeks are spent on multivariable calc. Every person in the class knows single variable calculus by heart; perhaps multi can be justified, but why are a full two weeks spent on material people know? And at the tail end of the semester, only two weeks are devoted to linear vector spaces and differential equations, which means both subjects are treated very superficially. People in this class have either seen the aforementioned material before and know it, or its their first go around, and theyre positively bewildered. The course needs to stop relying on Shankars text. There are so many other better mathematical methods textbooks out there that are not filled with errors and much more clearly written.
The professor is absolutely horrible. Steer clear of courses in which Professor Moncrief is teaching.

The course is a good attempt at providing a standard mathematical ability for all future Physics (or Mathematics and Physics) majors. It is a novel idea to put all of these major candidates on the same playing field by rendering their mathematical backgrounds irrelevant, but I think a couple things could have been done differently.

For starters, everyone in the class comes from a different math background. There are SENIOR Mathematics and Physics majors in that class, who undoubtedly have completed linear algebra, differential equations, multi-variable calculus - essentially the entire curriculum - and are just taking the class as an easy elective to count towards their major. And there are also other upperclassmen, who have seen most of the math in the course, but maybe aren't yet experts in, say, linear vector spaces. And then there are students like me - sophomores and intended physics majors who are required to take this course, either concurrently with, or prior to, any physics courses past introductory sequences.

For me, every topic was either (1) a waste of finite class time because I already knew how to do it from previous courses, or (2) totally unfamiliar to me and taught so quickly that I couldn't really learn any of it in the first place. The course bites off so much material, and covers it so rapidly, that it's hard to really learn things like linear vector spaces and differential equations in a few short weeks.

It should be ASSUMED, or required as a prerequisite, that every student in that class will have already taken single-variable calculus (both differential and integral, i.e. 'MATH 112' and 'MATH 115' or equivalent) at the minimum, if not multi-variable calculus, as well ('MATH 120'). I appreciated the multi-variable review, personally, but the four weeks we spent on single-variable calculus were, in my opinion, a waste of time, and a lost opportunity to spend more class time on linear vector spaces and differential equations. I spent over 12 hours total on the final problem set (linear vector spaces), including over an hour with Professor Moncrief himself, and ended up getting a 43% on it.

I put hardly any of this on Professor Moncrief - he is tasked with a great deal of material in a short period of time, with little to no knowledge of the various math backgrounds of each of his students. He doesn't really have any choice but to just reitorate Shankar's main points and move on. Rather, the curriculum of the course itself must be changed. Either the class needs to last two semesters, arranged in a topic progression consistent with concurrent physics courses, or some topics need to be removed from the curriculum to accommodate for the more difficult ones at the end.

Finally, Shankar's "Basic Training in Mathematics" seems to me like a fantastic reference to other textbooks and courses, but, like the structure of the class itself, is too quick and shallow in its dissection of the latter topics of the course,which a lot of students (at least this semester), like myself, simply have never seen before.

All in all, the course is a great idea. Establishing a basis (like in linear vector spaces... I remember that much!) for all physics or physics-related majors is a proactive way to avoid future mathematical hang-ups. But it's idealistic at best to think all of this can be done, to the extent necessary for a Yale physics student, in one semester.

If you've made it this far, thank you for reading this. I hope this fair review of the course will prove useful for the course and for students in future years.

Teddy Hague
Yale University Class of 2021
Branford College

If you want to learn a lot of math very fast and at a very superficial level, then this class is for you. This class is great to take before you take the math department versions of each topic: it allows you to see the material and become somewhat familiar with it. If you're still using Shankar's book in the future, then good luck. That book is horribly written and the problems are terrible. You'll spend more time figuring out what the questions are actually trying to ask than figuring out the math for the question.

This class is technically required for the physics major, but you should really just take linear algebra and/or diff eq and try to argue your way out of taking this class. I've heard that in the past (with a different professor) it wasn't so bad, but with Moncrief it was terrible. The class basically goes through "all the math you need for physics," which means everything from single-variable calculus to multivariable calculus to complex numbers to linear algebra to differential equations. I'm not sure why this class (which essentially has a multivariable prereq, based on the physics prereqs) needs to go so in depth on single variable calculus, but we spent way too much time on it and everything else we already knew. I was also really confused with who he thought was taking the class. He prefaced every (for real, every single) topic with "well I know most of you have seen this before." Why would we be taking the class if we knew it all before? 
When it got near the end of the semester, Moncrief realized he was running out of time, so we went through linear algebra really fast and barely got to diff eq, which were the only two reasons I took the class. 
Don't take this class if you can at all help it.

As long as the course exists in it's current form where it's taught based on the Shankar "Basic Training in Mathematics" book I say skip it and take the math dept courses or watch online lectures - you'll be much better off.
